channel.title: Things we hate about MMORPGS
channel.description:
I hate how most MMORPGS allow everyone to do the same quests, I mean really is the NPC so rich and has such a large spider infestation in his basement that he can reward every adventurer to go kill 10 of them?
Would it really be that hard to introduce a quest/task system that generated random quests throughout the world and give them to one player at a time.
Quests should also expire if you go offline, I mean really the mans house is full of rats and he needs someone to remove them why should he rely on the lazy fuck that disappears from the world?
I will say that I enjoyed world of Warcraft guide quests had been enjoyable because only one group at a time could preform them, but really that lazy night elf druid needs to be awaken with the horn everyday by multiple people?

item.dc:creator: @cooper cooper
item.description:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:50, topic:428194”][quote author=cooper link=topic=530887.msg3883109#msg3883109 date=1326216720]

I think a game like that would be awesome, I always though it would be cool to have a gameworld potentially honor those players that do great feats such as statues erected in memory of something they do, however something like that would also require being controlling of even the players in game name because if you had a statue of a player and his game was sirfkurmum it would bring the overall content down. Also I think by creating this sort of game you would have to generally limit the number of players in one world because everyone would want to be a part of shaping the world.

actually, a lot of MUDs operate like that. they enforce roleplay/have to approve names, but every action you take can have a lasting effect on the world. politics, housing, even magic in some (players have to “discover” its secrets) are almost completely managed by players. player moderators even help keep everything running smoothly.
[/quote]
which kind of follows my post about a small dedicated community, it would be near impossible to have this system work in a mainstream market.[/quote]
yeah, ive never seen one with a large playerbase integrate the players very well. even with some of the smaller ones, it’s not always easy for newer players to get involved

item.title: Things we hate about MMORPGS
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:30, topic:428194”]Not alot of people quest in WoW unless they don’t like dungeons or pvp. Dungeons are boring until 80 because at 80 the boss fights get significantly harder and you have to start getting good at timing and dodging rocks falling from the ceiling or a blast wave etc. Its really the raids that tell the story. When wotlk came out everyone rewatched the lore of arthas killing his father, and at the end of the final patch the ice crown citadel raid explained how he was killed and who took over.

I find that even if I don’t read the quests I will get a jist of what is going on in that area between the factions, but its still boring. Id save questing for games like skyrim really, where theres actually a story to tell.

EDIT: Actually spel since cata there are tons of quests that now have cutscenes and voice acting. At the start of cataclysm youre on an entire shipride with a general speaking to everyone about what may happen, and then a sea monster attacks etc. The voice acting is really good, its just the body animations are a bit lol. Honestly I think you may have stopped playing WoW too soon, pvp right around 60 really starts to get interesting, youre then able to fly everywhere on a flying mount which makes gathering alot easier and so are quests if you do them, at 80 dungeons start to really get strategic, and 85 raids are much harder 25-40 people on one boss trying not to be killed. And as we talked before boss doesnt just mean lots of health in wow, which I really enjoy (at 80 at least)[/quote]PvP without consequences do not interest me. If i cannot die and lose all my items, it feels meaningless.
